content: How can I help you today?

I guess I’m just here because my wife thinks I need to be. Things at home have been... tough, to say the least. My son’s behavior has been spiraling, and no matter what we do, nothing seems to help. It’s putting a massive strain on my marriage, and honestly, I don’t even know where to start.

Thank you for sharing that—it sounds like things have been really challenging for you. Balancing your son's behavior, the strain on your marriage, and figuring out where to start could feel overwhelming. Do you want to talk more about how this is affecting you personally and what you’re feeling amidst all of this?

It’s been exhausting, honestly. I feel like I can’t catch a break—between my son acting out, my wife and I constantly fighting, and just feeling like I can’t do anything right. I don’t even know how to fix this anymore. It just feels like it’s all falling apart.

That sounds incredibly heavy—feeling exhausted, stuck, and like the weight of everything is falling on your shoulders. It’s clear you care deeply about your family and want things to improve, but right now, it’s hard to see the way forward. What do you think has brought things to this point, or what feels hardest to deal with right now?

Honestly, it feels like everything's piled on all at once. My son’s behavior has been so challenging, and it causes constant tension between my wife and me. We're always arguing about what to do, and I feel like the harder we try, the worse everything gets. It’s just been really hard to see any light at the end of the tunnel.

It sounds like the tension within your family has been building, with your son's behavior presenting challenges that make it harder for you and your wife to feel united. It’s tough when it feels like your efforts aren’t leading to progress, and the weight of trying to fix things only adds to the strain. What helps you cope with moments when it all feels overwhelming?

To be honest, I don’t feel like I’ve been coping much at all. I don’t really feel like myself anymore—work feels impossible to focus on, and I can’t seem to enjoy anything I used to. It feels like I’m just stuck in this cycle with no way out.

It sounds like you’re feeling really disconnected from the things that used to ground you—work, enjoyment, and maybe even yourself—and that sense of being stuck adds to the weight you're carrying. Coping feels distant right now, and that’s a hard place to be. If there were even small steps toward breaking that cycle, what do you think they might look like for you?

Honestly, I don’t even know. I don’t feel like I have the energy or the clarity to figure out what those steps would be right now, and that’s part of what’s so frustrating. It’s like I don’t even know where to start, and things just keep piling up.

That frustration makes sense—you’re already handling so much, and trying to figure out where to begin when you feel drained can seem impossible. It’s okay to not have it all figured out right now. Maybe starting small, even just reflecting on moments where things feel slightly less overwhelming, could be helpful. What do you think of that idea?

I don’t know... I guess it makes sense. I just feel like even the "small things" are hard to figure out right now. It’s hard to notice when anything feels less overwhelming because I’m just always on edge, you know? Like, I want things to get better, but it’s hard to see the point in trying sometimes.

That constant feeling of being on edge sounds exhausting—when it’s hard to even notice moments of relief, it can make everything feel endless. But the fact that you’re here and expressing a desire for things to get better shows that you haven’t given up, even if it feels hopeless at times. What do you think keeps you holding onto that hope, even in the midst of how hard it’s been?

I guess what keeps me going is my family. As much as I feel like things are falling apart, I love my wife and kids, and I don’t want to let them down. I want things to be better for them, even if I’m not sure how to get there right now.

Your love for your family shines through, even in the middle of all the struggles you're facing. Wanting better for your wife and kids speaks to how deeply you care about them and your connection to them, even when things are tough. Holding onto that has been keeping you moving, even when the way forward feels unclear. How do you imagine things being different for your family if you found that path to change?

I guess I imagine us being happy again—less fighting, less stress. My wife and I being able to support each other instead of constantly arguing. My son feeling more stable and happy, and having the time and energy to really connect with my daughter too. I miss when we all felt like a team instead of everything being this... mess.

That vision of a happier, calmer family and feeling like a team again sounds really meaningful. It shows how much you value connection and stability for everyone, including yourself. Even with everything feeling messy now, imagining that better future gives a sense of what you’re working toward. Is there anything else you’d like to reflect on before exploring next steps or ways forward?

I think that's really what it comes down to—I just want things to feel okay again. But honestly, I don't even know if that's possible anymore. It's hard to imagine how to get from where we are to there. Maybe it just feels too far off right now.

It’s tough to see a path forward when everything feels so far away from the life you want for your family—it’s an understandable feeling. But even the act of sharing your hopes and struggles here shows you’re open to exploring what might be possible, even if it feels uncertain now. Would you be open to talking about small steps that could help you feel less stuck, or would you like to spend more time here for reflection? It’s your call.

That’s completely understandable—it can feel impossible to see a way forward when the road ahead seems so overwhelming. You’ve shared so much already, and that’s a huge step toward untangling everything. Maybe we could think together about what one small change, even something very simple, could start to make things feel a little more manageable. Does anything come to mind?

Thank you for being open. Even in a tough spot, the effort you’re taking to make sense of things shows your strength. If you're unsure about next steps, we could look at something very small, like focusing on a bit of time each day to recharge, or finding a moment for you and your wife to connect amidst the chaos. Or we could explore more of what’s been weighing on you first—what feels right to you?
